title: My favorite restaurant.
text:
I was in Paris last November where I made 51 films which you can see on my channel; “Art and Travel by Dave.” This is the last of them. But if you like fine dining, I have saved the best for last.

Taillevent is a restaurant in Paris, founded in 1946 by André Vrinat, and now owned by the Gardinier family.

I had my first meal at Taillevent in 1989 at the tender age of 30. Lunch was $235. It was the best meal I had ever had. I forgot what my wife and I started with but she ordered Coquille St. Jaques for the main course. It was game season and I had a quail, duck, and pheasant with fois gras in a pastry shell in a brown reduction sauce. Nice and Light. It was the best thing I had ever eaten.

Back then you could smoke in restaurants. I smoked Dunhills at the time and each pack of twenty was divided by two with a separate tin foil compartment for each. When one of the wait staff noticed I had finished my tenth cigarette, he took my pack, opened it, and removed the tin foil from the other ten cigarettes. Talk about service.

Then we switched plates. They would not let us. They whisked them away, freshly prepared them, and brought them to us under the same silver canopies which covered them when they were first brought out.

Then it came time for dessert. When we tried to order, they wouldn’t let us. They said we will order for you. And after I said; “Wait a minute…” they were off. They came back with a triple mousse for me and a pear tart al a mode for my wife. We could not have chosen better.

I have recommended this to friends, all of whom have similar stories.

I ate at Taillevent again in 2008 with my wife and two girls. It was not so memorable.

We went to Spain where we had the pleasure of eating at El Cellar De Can Roca in Girona, at that time rated the best restaurant in the world. It was, simply put, the most amazing meal I had ever had. You can see a video of it on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. The prix-fix menu was 600 Euros.

In the fall of 2019, (remember when the world was normal?) I returned to Taillevent after eating at two, three star Micheline restaurants in Paris. It did not disappoint. You can see the film on my channel. A five course prefix menu was only 350 Euros. Supremely creative cuisine which charged the taste buds and service as it was meant to be. It was one of the greatest three meals of my life.

My friend, James, who accompanied me, first turned me on to Taillevent in The 1980’s. He is an accomplished chef and has had the same experience with this fine restaurant that I have.

title: La Tour D'Argent is the Grande Dame of French restaurants.
text:
La Tour D'Argent is the Grande Dame of French restaurants. It was a great restaurant and then fell into decline. It is said that the fil; “Ratatouille,” is based on La Tour D'Argent. I ate there with my family and was not disappointed. I had the very best fois gras that I ever had and the best chocolate mousse. We ordered the duck which was splendid. The mille fois was spectacular.

You can see a video of the meal on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: How To Visit The Louvre in 2 Hours, 3 Hours, 4, or more.
text:
See a film of this primer on visiting the Louvre and 42 films of the museum entitles; "The Complete Louvre," on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

If you are only visiting for one day, be certain that the rooms you wish to see are open. I’ve just spent five full days at The Louvre making a comprehensive film of the museum. All rooms are open on the weekends. The small French Paintings and Northern European Art are closed two days per week.

The Pyramid: You want to avoid this entrance. Just make sure that you are on the correct line. Those with tickets or the museum pass can use the shorter line on the left.

The first trick is to use The Richelieu entrance. It is opposite The Rivoli Metro Stop and to the left of the main entrance. This is good for those with memberships and electronic tickets. If you get there first thing, by nine, they often do not check. Also, this is the best exit. The other exit is under The Carousel, where they steer you to shop. Do try to avoid this.

It’s best to look at The Louvre as three separate museums: The Denon Wing, The Richelieu Wing, and The Sully Wing. Any one day ticket allows three entries at any of the wings. So you can get a bite or a cup of coffee in between your visits to each wing. If you want to go back to the same wing, you will miss out on a different wing. Do note that you can get into The Sully Wing from The Richelieu Wing and vice versa. So if you want to take more breaks under the pyramid, you can use this scheme.

So, tip number two: Get there early. If you had to visit one museum at opening time, this would be the one. Naturally, have your museum pass or ticket in hand.

If you want to see our lady of The Louvre, go to The Denon wing and bear right up the stairs. You will get to a hallway with The Winged Victory on your right. To your left are the two Michelangelo’s Slaves, including The Dying Slave. Behind you is Roman art. Ascend to the Winged Victory and make a right.

Now gander upon the Grand Gallery, and take your time. To your immediate right is a section of International Gothic and Early renaissance art. If this is not your cup of tea, skip it. But examine the three Giotto’s on your left. This is where renaissance painting began. Move slowly up until The Mona Lisa room. This is, to me, one of the best parts of the museum. Go past The Mona Lisa room to see The Raphael’s and stop when you see The Voltera; David Slaying Goliath in the middle facing you. There is a bathroom to your right.

Unless you are keen on Baroque art, go no further. If you are, continue to The Caravaggio’s and then turn back to The Mona Lisa Room. There are a fair amount of Leonardo’s outside this room, which have been temporarily moved to The Leonardo Exhibition. Please see my film on this exhibit. Stand in the airplane security line to see her and don’t dismiss the art surrounding it, especially The Wedding at Cana by Veronese behind you.

After Mona, go behind her to see the fantastic “Pastoral Concert” by Titian, though I think it to be a Giorgione. It inspired many an artwork, not the least of which: Manet’s “Luncheon on The Grass,” across the river at The D’Orsay.

You emerge on the other side at Great French Historical Paintings. They are not all historical but they are all great. Here you will see the biggies: The Raft of The Medusa, The Coronation of Napoleon, and Liberty Leading The People. Turn right to The Winged Victory and descend the stairs. Go straight ahead To The Michelangelos at the far end. If your goal was a two hour visit, you are done. You can proudly say that you have visited The Louvre.

If you wish to expand your visit to three hours and Renaissance sculpture appeals to you, go down the stairs behind The Michelangelos.

Then, ascend the stairs and go to where you came in. There is a great collection of Roman statues next to the exit.

Then go to The Sully Wing to see The Venus D’Milo. The go upstairs to see the small French paintings, such as Watteau, Chardin, Boucher, Fragonard and Ingres. This will put you at the three hour mark.

You can, of course go through their mammoth Egypt collection but be forewarned if you go in, it will take about two hours to get out. The same holds true for their oriental section, which is really middle eastern art. Also the myriad of French decorative art will take up two hours as well.

title: a great museum for any American
text: This is a great museum for any American. See the lives, culture, and equipment that led us to victory in WWII. To see a film of this museum, visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: A nice little museum
text: A nice little museum that is inexpensive and not very time consuming. Be sure to hear the speech by the docent as it will put it all into context. To see a film of this museum, visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave

title: The National Gallery of Art is a treasure
text:
The National Gallery of Art is a treasure and especially now so with The Verrocchio exhibit. See a video of this exhibit on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

Aside from the fact that this is one of the two best museums in America, it is laid out perfectly. It has a marvelous collection of renaissance, baroque, Dutch, and French Art. It's American collection is second to none and watch for a video of that collection on my channel!

title: A splendid visit, especially in the fall.
text:
As we come upon the fall, consider visiting Olana, America's Giverny. Frederic Church designed the landscape and worked closely with architect Calvert Vaux (think Central Park) to build his distinctive home.

The inside tour in unnecessary. The outdoor tram ride is lovely but even without either of theses tours, it's wonderful just to walk around the grounds, which is free.

If you wish to see a video of the property, visit my channel: Art and Travel by Dave on YouTube.

title: gone downhill
text:
I have been eating at Donavan’s Pub in Woodside for over 40 years. It used to be a friendly place and was awarded the best burger in NY by one of the local papers. Then the owners sold off their restaurant both there and in their Bayside location. It has since gone downhill whereas The Bayside location is classier, has better food, and friendlier service.

I ordered a medium rare burger and it was raw. I sent it back and the very same burger, with my two bites taken out of it, was returned to me medium well. I didn’t complain and ate my burger.

I asked for the manager, Chris. Two weeks prior I had picked up an order and when I returned to my building, I found the order was wrong. I called Donavan’s, spoke to Chris, and he said that he would give me a free burger the next time I came in. But Chris wasn’t there. I spoke to another manager who told me that Chris had no authorization to give me a free burger unless he were to pay it for himself. I replied; “Do you think that I am trying to scam you out of an F’ing burger? At this point the manager told me I was no longer welcome in the restaurant.

I waited for my check but instead a bellicose troglodyte came up to my table and started berating me. He may have been the owner. He wore a baseball cap. Finally, I could take no more, put my business card on the bar and said; “send me a bill.”

I walked out and the troglodyte followed me. At this point he had the wonderful idea to call Chris. I do not know what Chris said since all I heard was the troglodyte’s insults calling me a male appendage. I tried to calm down by walking around the block as he followed me, took pictures of me, and insulted me calling me names for all of Woodside to hear. Then when I calmed down, I tried to go in and pay but the troglodyte blocked the door and told me I couldn’t pay now.

I had taken business associates to Donavan’s Pub for decades. I took relatives there from out of town. We have even had our company Christmas parties there. Needless to say, Donavan’s Pub in Woodside will never see my shadow again. I will eat at the Bayside location as I have from time to time, where my fiend’s sister is the manager and where they treat their customers with the proper respect.

title: If you were to visit one synagogue in New York...
text:
If you were to visit one synagogue in New York, this would be the one. It stood on a block that was the heart of The Lower East Side and the very first built by the new wave of Jewish Immigrants. The inside is lovely and you get a real feeling of what it was like for Jews to pray here over 100 years ago.

To see what there is to see here, please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see The Eldridge Street Synagogue.

title: Boring
text:
Nafplion is where tour guides take their tourists for lunch and shopping in between Mycenae and Epidaurus. You can see videos of these sites. See below.

Palamidi Castle is the main site and it is very boring. But it does have a great view, which you can see in muy film; "Greece is the Word." I only went there because I had some time to kill. I recommend Nafplion for lunch-- that's it.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece is The Word.

title: Not for the timid
text:
Super Paradise Beach is a nice enough beach but this is where you go to party and dance on the bar! Not for the timid, like me. To see the mayhem, watch the video mentioned below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece is The Word.

title: the quality of the art is mediocre
text:
Cathedral of Saint John the Baptist is a nice little church but like so many Greek Orthodox churches, the quality of the art is mediocre. It is worth a look for 5 or 10minutes and you can see the exterior and interior in the video listed below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece: Santorini.
place: Cathedral of Saint John the Baptist

title: Also known as The Black Beach
text:
Also known as The Black Beach, the sand is great and the water fantastic. There are a few places to eat nearby or to buy provisions for a picnic.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece: Santorini.

title: Wow these reviews are harsh!
text:
Wow these reviews are harsh! But I have to admit, the museum is poor. It has hardly any interesting artifacts and many of the pictures here are from the other museum in Fira: Museum of Prehistoric Thira, which is terrific. I made a video of each museum I visited and Greece except for this one. You can see the lion in my video mentioned below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece: Santorini.

title: you can go to Kastro, which is always crowded or...
text:
Sunset on Santorini is best seen from Oia. Now you can go to Kastro, which is always crowded or you can go see sunset behind the blue domes. From the main square, turn right. Second alley- Make a left and go down for a great view.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece: Santorini.

title: beautiful to behold
text:
The Red Beach is wonderful and beautiful to behold. What’s just as good, is the restaurant down the road; Dolphins Fish Taverna which prides itself in having the freshest fish every day which comes from their own boat. To see the beach and my meal look at the video below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Greece: Santorini.

title: See the oldest frescoes in the world
text:
he Museum of Prehistoric Thira houses finds from the excavations at Akrotiri. This is the greatest museum on Santorini and a must see if you are interested in Cycladic Art. Here you will find the oldest frescoes in the world, from before 2,500 B.C. Realize that the Ancient Thirans were as ancient to the Ancient Greeks as they are to us. It is a small museum and you can see it in under an hour.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Santorini: The Prehistoric Museum at Fira.

title: not for me
text:
Mykonos was not for me. I am 60 and my kids wanted to go to Mykonos where they began drinking as soon as they got there and fell asleep at about nine. That said, there is one thing to see: The Windmills. Go there before sunset, stake out your spot, and wait. You may get a shot like the one below. The beaches are nice but the only thing of interest is The Island of Delos a 30 minute boat ride way. You can see my film, David Does Delos. See below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To see girls dancing on the bar, see Greece is The Word.

title: The most important thing to see on Delos
text:
Delos was the center of The Delian League, which made Delos what it was and is. Look it up! Avenue of the Lions was meant to impress. It is the most important thing to see on Delos but don’t be fooled—These are copies. The originals are in the fine museum. See the picture.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see David Does Delos.

title: a 30 minute boat ride from Mykonos
text:
The Archaeological Museum of Delos is noted for its extensive collection of statues unearthed in the surrounding area of the ancient site, which has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It's a 30 minute boat ride from Mykonos and well worth it. Delos was the center of The Delian League, which made Delos what it was and is. Look it up! The Frieze from The Siphnian Treasury is a major work and explained very well in my video. See Below. More famous is The Charioteer. See the picture.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see David Does Delos.

title: The Temple of Isis is a must see.
text:
While your kids are dancing at or on the bar in Mykonos, do visit Delos. It's a 30 minute boat ride and well worth it. Delos was the center of The Delian League, which made Delos what it was and is. Look it up! The Temple of Isis is a must see. It is, for the most port, the furthest site from the port and where people generally turn around. Do yourself a favor and walk ten feet further and you will see a unique Greek statue; a headless torso with her arms crossed. I have never seen that in Greek statuary. See the picture.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see David Does Delos.

title: While your kids are dancing at or on the bar in Mykonos...
text:
While your kids are dancing at or on the bar in Mykonos, do visit Delos. It's a 30 minute boat ride and well worth it. The Archaeological Site is best seen with a guide. But The museum (not to be missed), The Lions and The Temple of Isis require no guide at all.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see David Does Delos.

title: a site to behold!
text:
Epidaurus includes the sanctuary of Asclepios, which was a healing center and cultural center, built in 4th Century BC., making it the first hospital. But the real draw here is the ancient Theatre of Epidaurus. It is the largest theater from Ancient Greece and a site to behold!

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Epidaurus.

title: The Museum is the highlight
text:
On your way to Mycenae is Ancient Corinth. I really wanted to see it but no tours included it on their itinerary so I hired a private car for the day. If you are traveling with a few people it is the same price as a Viator tour. I found a Great Private Car Company – George 30-695-596-7896 for only 200 for Argolis Tour of Ancient Corinth, Mycenae, and lunch at Nafplion. On a private tour you would spend a couple of hours eating and shopping which held little interest for me. Then we went to Epidaurus to see the largest theater in Greece.

The Temple of Apollo towers over the ruins of Ancient Corinth. The site itself is interesting but the museum is even more so. It has large statues as well as some very fine mosaics.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Ancient Corinth.

title: The museum of Mycenae is not to be missed.
text:
On your way to Mycenae is Ancient Corinth. I really wanted to see it but no tours included it on their itinerary so I hired a private car for the day. If you are traveling with a few people it is the same price as a Viator tour. I found a Great Private Car Company – George 30-695-596-7896 for only 200 for Argolis Tour of Ancient Corinth, Mycenae, and lunch at Nafplion. On a private tour you would spend a couple of hours eating and shopping which held little interest for me. Then we went to Epidaurus to see the largest theater in Greece.

The museum of Mycenae is not to be missed. Mycenean art is fairly rare and while the museum doesn’t have any big statues, it has charming small statues of Mycenean women throwing their arms up in the air. It also has a copy of “The Mask of Agamemnon,” the original of which is in Athens’ national Archaeological museum. I made a film of that museum as well. See below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Mycenae.

title: The biggest dome of antiquity
text:
On your way to Mycenae is Ancient Corinth. I really wanted to see it but no tours included it on their itinerary so I hired a private car for the day. If you are traveling with a few people it is the same price as a Viator tour. I found a Great Private Car Company – George 30-695-596-7896 for only 200 for Argolis Tour of Ancient Corinth, Mycenae, and lunch at Nafplion. On a private tour you would spend a couple of hours eating and shopping which held little interest for me. Then we went to Epidaurus to see the largest theater in Greece.

The Treasury of Atreus or Tomb of Agamemnon is a large tholos or beehive tomb. It is also the largest dome built until 1,500 years later: The Pantheon. Parenthetically, it took another 1,500 years to build a bigger dome: The Duomo in Florence (You can see a film about this on my channel, see below.

Don’t miss the museum of Mycenae.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Mycenae.

title: Get a private car.
text:
On your way to Mycenae is Ancient Corinth. I really wanted to see it but no tours included it on their itinerary so I hired a private car for the day. If you are traveling with a few people it is the same price as a Viator tour.

I found a Great Private Car Company – George 30-695-596-7896 for only 200 for Argolis Tour of Ancient Corinth, Mycenae, and lunch at Nafplion. On a private tour you would spend a couple of hours eating and shopping which held little interest for me. Then we went to Epidaurus to see the largest theater in Greece.

You can't miss The Lion's Gate as you pass through its huge Cyclopean Walls. The Palace, was reached by a large ramp beginning at the Lions Gate. Outside lies beehive tombs including one ascribed to Agamemnon known also as the Treasury of Atreas.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see Mycenae.

title: If you have some extra time after Delphi
text:
Driving up Parnassos you can visit the famous monastery of Ossios Loukas, the largest surviving monastery of the Middle Byzantine period in Greece, founded in the early 10th century by the hermit St. Loukas whose relics are kept there to this day. The Katholikon has some of the best preserved Byzantine mosaics. The monastery’s courtyard has a spectacular mountain view.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. To determine if this site is for you, see The Monastery of Ossios Loukas.

title: Not much of a mountain
text:
Not much of a mountain—Sorry Apollo but the valley of Delphi is a beauty to behold. If you are visiting The Monastery of Ossios Loukas, you can’t miss Mount Parnassus. Just don’t expect Apollo and his nymphs on top of it.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see The Monastery of Ossios Loukas.

title: not much to see
text:
The Tholos is nice but there’s not much to see. You can even see it form a little terrace aside the road if you are too tired after seeing all the action up the hill, as my kids were. As far as what is above:

I can’t imagine going all the way to Delphi and not visiting the museum. This is one of the best museums in Greece. The Chariotter, seen below, is one of the greatest surviving Greek Bronzes. The story of Kleobis and Biton should really be understood before viewing. The frieze from The Siphnian Treasury is tells two very special stories. Watch the video which explains all of it referred to below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see David Does Delphi.

title: One of the best museums in Greece
text:
I can’t imagine going all the way to Delphi and not visiting the museum. This is one of the best museums in Greece. The Chariotter, seen below, is one of the greatest surviving Greek Bronzes. The story of Kleobis and Biton should really be understood before viewing. The frieze from The Siphnian Treasury is tells two very special stories. Watch the video which explains all of it referred to below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see David Does Delphi.

title: The Temple of Apollo can’t be missed
text:
Before entering Delphi, be sure to take a drink from the sacred spring outside, to cleanse your soul before going to the Temple. The Temple of Apollo can’t be missed but continue trekking up the hill to see the Theater and the Hippodrome. Do not miss the museum, which is one of Greece’s finest.
To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see David Does Delphi.

title: If you are going to take one trip outside of Athens
text:
If you are going to take one trip outside of Athens, it should be Delphi. Zeus sent two birds from the edges of Greece and when they met, they found “The Navel of The World.” And it really looks like it too! See, The Temple of Apollo and one of the most splendid sites in Greece. The museum is fantastic. Pay special attention to The Siphnian Treasury. You will see it’s remains as you ascend and the splendid frieze from it in the museum. Also, the great bronze: Charioteer.
To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see David Does Delphi.

title: The Parthenon really can’t be missed.
text:
The Parthenon really can’t be missed. Just look to the right of The Erechtheion. It took 15 years to build and for the last 30 years, it has been restored. They actually took all the drums of each and every column down and reassembled them to right the wrongs of past reconstructions, so you shouldn’t see any of the scaffolding I was subjected to when I was there. See the picture below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see On and Around The Acropolis.

title: The Erechtheion really can’t be missed.
text:
The Erechtheion really can’t be missed. Just look to the left of The Parthenon. The caryatids are supposedly females who betrayed The Greeks to The Persians, so they must carry their burden through the ages. Around the back is The Olive Tree that Athena planted (which has been replaced) and the hole in the foundation where Poseidon flooded the mountain with seawater.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see On and Around The Acropolis.

title: The Acropolis Museum is more or less a must.
text:
The Acropolis Museum is more or less a must. It was built in the hopes that The Parthenon (Elgin) Marbles would be returned from The British Museum, but they did not hold their breath. It has copies of these marbles as well as some fun things like a Lego Parthenon. It holds the original caryatids seen on The Erechtheion on The Acropolis. It also has fantastic Archaic Statues and the biggest collection of Kores (female youths) anywhere in the world. Sadly, these, and the amazing Kritios Boy cannot be photographed.

The best models are the models of the pediments which include the greatest sculptural programs ever built and are for the most part, lost. You can see a video of The Acropolis and museum on my YouTube channel.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: How can you not visit The Acropolis?
text:
It is best to visit really early or really late. Wear comfortable shoes. Bring water as nothing is for sale within the complex.You may wish to visit The Acropolis museum before your visit to understand what you are seeing. Or....

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, see On and Around The Acropolis.

title: A must see and don't just look through the fence
text:
A must see and don't just look through the fence. An easy walk from The Agora or Acropolis, you should really see these titanic columns up close. You will also get a view of The Acropolis in the background, which you can see in the picture below.

To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. For this site, watch On and Around The Acropolis.

title: Worth a peek after The Agora or Acropolis
text: While not really worth a special trip, it is worth a peek after The Agora or Acropolis. It is the first structure to use the Corinthian order. You can see a picture of it below. To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: The Ancient Agora is not a "must see, but...
text: When visiting The Ancient Agora, you will first see the rebuilt the restored Stoa of Attalos, which has some nice artefacts. The main thing is that it has a bathroom and a cold water fountain. You can take your time strolling the paths that saw Aristotle’s shadow but the main attraction is The Temple of Hephaestus, which is the most intact Greek Temple in the world. You can see a picture of it below. To see what there is to see here, and all around Greece (many with closed caption explanations), please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: The must see museum in Athens
text:
This is a must see museum in Athens. You will see the very best of ancient Greek art here. Go early to avoid the crowds. Do not miss the Thera room on the second floor which contain the oldest frescoes in the world.

To see a film of what the museum has to offer, check it out on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: the second best museum in Athens
text: This is the second best museum in Athens after The National Archaeological Museum. It has the finest collection of large Cycladic statues in the world. It is well worth a visit and the whole museum can be seen in under two hours. The museum also has a small collection of Greek art and Cypriot art, which is hosed in a surrounding that looks like a star ship. to see a film of this museum, please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: As picturesque as it gets.
text: Aside from The Parthenon, The Temple of Poseidon on Cape Sounion is what we most imagine when we picture Ancient Greece. Its image adorns countless book and video covers. It is best seen at sunset but it is an hour south of Athens. Public transportation is sketchy after sunset and forget about finding a taxi there. So take a taxi, which will cost about 150 Euros round trip, including waiting time. Negotiate the price up front. Another option is to rent a car and use it the next day to visit Delphi or Corinth and Mycenae. To see a two minute video of the site, please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: Terrible Hotel
text:
I booked this hotel six months ago and within 10 minutes I realized I made a mistake as to the dates. I called Expedia and was told they could only refund me or change the dates if Red Roof Inn agreed. They did not, even within twenty minutes of my reservation. That said, I had to pay for three nights, only one of which I used.

The room's toilet did not work. The phone did not work. When they came to fix the toilet, they said they had fixed the flapper. One flush after they left it broke again.

Upon inspecting the flapper, I saw that it was unable to be fixed and needed to be replaced for it to work two times in a row.

Oh, and they don't have cots so my daughter had to sleep on eh floor.

Stay away.
place: Red Roof Inn Binghamton - Johnson City

title: Not the reason to go to Arezzo but...
text:
Not the reason to go to Arezzo but as long as you are there, why not visit this lovely church before or after St. Francis. Because near to the cenotaph is Piero della Francesca's Mary Magdalene (1460s).

You can see a video of this church in Dave's Arezzo File at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: The Met is the greatest museum in the world.
text:
The Met is the greatest museum in the world. The encyclopedic nature, the lighting, and the compactness. You can see 5,000 years of art in just three hours.

To see videos of certain departments, as well as two current exhibitions, please visit my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: The real star here is Duccio
text:
The real star here is Duccio and his Maestà which you can see on the first floor. The second floor is ho-hum except that you can go up to the roof to see a nice view of the church and a splendidview of The Campo.

You can see a video of this museum at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: Does anyone go to Siena without visiting the Cathedral?
text:
Does anyone go to Siena without visiting the Cathedral? This is one of the must beautiful churches in Europe and unique. It's best to buy The Cathedral, Museum, Baptistry, Crypt package. A who’s who of artists have contributed to The Cathedral:The Piccolomini library includes amazing frescoes by Pinturicchio and The Piccolomini Altar contains two sculptures by Michelangelo.

The Baptistry or Battistero di San Giovanni contains a Baptismal Font for which six bronze reliefs were made by The DREAM Team of 1420’s sculptors, including: Donatello, Ghiberti, and Jacopo della Quercia.

A descent into the very entrails of the Cathedral, leads to an area commonly known as the "Crypt" and unquestionably one of the most important archaeological discoveries of the past twenty years.

You can see a video of all these sites at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: The reason one goes to Arezzo
text:
The Basilica Of St Francis if the reason one goes to Arezzo. The Bacci Chapel, has frescoes of the Legend of the True Cross, by Piero della Francesca. These frescoes are some of the most important north of The Sistine Chapel. Beware-- You need to make an appointment.

You can see a video of this church at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: Terrific Hotel
text: Terrific Hotel with a perfect location and a friendly staff. It was very economical with a decent breakfast. I didn't have the correct charging adapter and they loaned me one. Highly recommended, just steps from The Duomo.

title: Don't miss Casa Vasari
text:
If you find yourself in Arezzo, don't miss Casa Vasari. Naturally The Basilica Of St Francis is the draw here but this is a lovely site. It was decorated by Vasari himelf and has gorgeous ceiling frescoes. It is a little out of the way but worth the walk!

You can see a video of this museum at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: You can't go to Florence and miss The Ponte Vecchio.
text: You can't go to Florence and miss The Ponte Vecchio. Go early for a more deserted ambiance. I don't know if it's wise to purchase jewelry there. You can see a good view of and on the bridge, as well as other Florence highlights in the film; "Florence by Day," at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. There are 21 other films about Florence on my channel.

title: Best to visit at night
text:
It's best to visit at night when it is less crowded. The Loggia Lanzi is one of the best out door porticos in the world. See the picture (You will normally see a cop car in front of it at night, which is why I asked him to move for this picture.

You can see more of the piazza in my film, "Florence by Night," at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. There are 21 other films about Florence on my channel.

title: The Outside is more important than the inside.
text:
The only reason that I gave this 4 starts is that he Outside is more important than the inside. The panels on the doors by Pisano, and even more so those by Ghiberti are the most important bronze panels of the Renaissance. The originals are in The Museo del Opera del Duomo. To buy tickets for these two sites, the ticket office is to the right of The Baptistry, if you are facing away from The Duomo.

Again, the inside is nice, with a mural on the ceiling but the doors are the draw.

You can see a video of The Duomo, Baptistry, Campinile, at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave. There are 21 other films about Florence on my channel.

title: If you are reading this to decide whether to go or not, you are visiting the wrong city.
text:
If you are reading this to decide whether to go or not, you are visiting the wrong city. It, along with The David, are the two "must sees" of Florence.

Tip: For a Great Free view of The Duomo visit The Caffetteria delle Oblate - Oblate Public Library, Via dell'Oriuolo, 24. This public library Oblate is right behind the Duomo and the top floor has a gorgeous terrace. Open Monday 2-7pm, Tuesday-Saturday 9am-midnight.

You can see a video of The Duomo at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.
place: Duomo - Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore

title: One of the most beautiful synagogues in Europe
text:
The Sinagoga di Firenze e Museo ebraico is one of the most beautiful synagogues in Europe, or anywhere else. This is a must see if you are Jewish. The museum is very small but worth seeing.

You can see a video of The Synagogue and museum at my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.
place: Sinagoga di Firenze e Museo ebraico

title: A beautiful church built by Filippo Brunelleschi
text:
San Spirito is a beautiful church built by Filippo Brunelleschi, the great architect who built the dome of The Duomo. His other buildings include The Pazzi Chapel at Santa Croce and the interior of The Church of San Lorenzo.

It is a beautiful Renaissance style church, almost identical to that of San Lorenzo.Especially worth seeing is the crucifix carved by Michelangelo if it is on display.

You can see one shot of this church in my film: Florence: The Smaller Churches of Firenze on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave, as I learned that photography was not allowed.

title: One of Perugino's best frescoes
text:
Santa Maria Maddalena dei Pazzi is a nice little church but the star attraction is arround the corner where you can see The Crucifixion by Perugino. TIP: It's like many sites with changing opening times. The fresco is in a school, which you can call at: 0552478420. When I was there it was open Tuesdays and Thursdays from 10.00am-12.00am and 5.00pm-6.30pm. But better call first.

This is one of Perugino's best frescoes. It's really worth seeing. It is also good to pair this visit with: Cenacolo di Sant'Apollonia, The grisaille frescoes of del Sarto at The Cloister of The Scalzo , Cenacolo di Sant'Apollonia, and The Museo Ospedale degli Innocenti (The Foundling Hospital) as they are all very close.

You can see a complete video of this church in my film: Florence: The Smaller Churches of Firenze on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: a real hidden gem
text:
The Cloister of The Scalzo is a real hidden gem and as unusual a find as you will see in Florence. The cloister was decorated by del Sarto with about ten grisaille (black and white) frescoes of the life of St. John The Baptist. This is a worthwhile fifteen minutes!

It is also good to pair this visit with: Cenacolo di Sant'Apollonia, Santa Maria Maddalena dei Pazzi with it's Crucifixion by Perugino, Cenacolo di Sant'Apollonia, and The Museo Ospedale degli Innocenti (The Foundling Hospital) as they are all very close.

You can see a complete video of this church in my film: Florence: The Smaller Churches of Firenze on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.

title: Santissima Annunziata is not quite a "must see,"
text:
Santissima Annunziata is not quite a "must see," but it is the only Baroque church in Florence. The ornate walls and ceiling are magnificent.

It is also good to pair this visit with: Cenacolo di Sant'Apollonia, Santa Maria Maddalena dei Pazzi with it's Crucifixion by Perugino, Cenacolo di Sant'Apollonia, and The Museo Ospedale degli Innocenti (The Foundling Hospital) as they are all very close.

You can see a video of this church in my film: Florence: The Smaller Churches of Firenze on my YouTube channel: Art and Travel by Dave.
place: Basilica della Santissima Annunziata - Chiesa di Santa Maria della Scala
